description: From Latin vibrātus, perfect passive participle of vibrō (“agitate, set in tremulous motion”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *weyp- (“to oscillate, swing”) or *weyb-.

entries.meaning: The setting, on a portable electronic device, that causes it to vibrate rather than sound any (or most) needed alarms.
examples: Please put your cellphones on vibrate for the duration of the meeting.

verbs.description: vibrate (third-person singular simple present vibrates, present participle vibrating, simple past and past participle vibrated)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To shake with small, rapid movements to and fro.

examples: Her mind was vibrating with excitement.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To brandish; to swing to and fro.
examples: to vibrate a sword or a staff

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark or measure by moving to and fro.
(transitive) To affect with vibratory motion; to set in vibration.
(transitive, slang, dated) To please or impress someone.
examples: And if he wants to give you high praise, he'll answer, "That vibrates me"; "That has a large charge"; or "That's oogley."
